MODding Sound

 

To add sounds to your MOD, you should first author the sounds as uncompressed, 16-bit, 48K wav files. Mono, stereo, and 6-channel wavs are supported, but only mono sounds can be positioned in the world. The wavs should be placed in a subdirectory under the MOD SDK root folder\audio.  (which corresponds to the “AUDIO:” label in the XML files.) Then create an <AudioFile> XML entry referencing that .wav file.

 

The name of the directory containing the wavs is VERY important! If the directory is named “Sounds”, the Audio Compiler will, by default, set the sound file to be XAS-compressed and unstreamed (that is, the entire sound will be loaded into memory first, and then played). This is an appropriate default for most sound effects, unit responses, and EVA announcements. If the directory containing the wavs is named anything else, the Audio Compiler will default to leaving the sound uncompressed and will stream the sound from disk when played. All of these defaults can be overridden using attributes of the <AudioFile> entry. Due to disk bandwidth limitations, care should be taken that only a small number of streaming sounds are played at one time; most sounds should be unstreamed.

 

A note on compression types: The Audio Compiler supplied with the C&C3 MODKit supports two compression types – uncompressed and XAS-compressed. Uncompressed sounds are large and take a lot of bandwidth to stream, but the quality is excellent and they take little CPU to play. XAS compression is similar to ADPCM compression. It gets a decent compression ratio (better than 3:1), and takes little CPU to play, but the compression can cause sound distortion, especially of sounds with large dynamic ranges (sounds with both high and low frequencies). You may notice a third type of compression listed in the XSD and XML files named “EALayer3”; unfortunately, due to licensing restrictions, we are unable to include the EALayer3 compressor with the C&C3 MODKit.

 

In its place, we have provided you with the ability to play MP3 files directly. To use this, place the MP3 file somewhere under data\rts_sourceart_audio\0.0-dev, and then create an <AudioFileMP3Passthrough> entry, such as

 

        <AudioFileMP3Passthrough id="example" File="AUDIO:tracks\example.mp3" />.

 

The Audio Compiler will copy the MP3 file into the built data. You can play such MP3 files using the <MP3MusicTrack>, <MP3DialogEvent>, or <MP3AmbientStream> XML entries. Note that it is not possible to use MP3 files in an <AudioEvent>.

 

There are several special considerations when using the MP3 Passthrough feature. First, MP3 files must be mono or stereo files. When looping, there will be a small gap between each playthrough, so be sure that any looping MP3s begin and end in silence. Also, be aware that on low-end machines, it will require 1% of the CPU to play each MP3 channel, and there is a hard limit of 13 MP3 files playing at once, so you should generally use the MP3 Passthrough system only when you have a large file which needs it. Music, long speeches (especially long speeches in scripted missions), and long ambient streams are the main intended applications.

 

Finally, special notes on load screen music: In order to minimize level-load times, music used on level load screens should be unstreamed. This is done by adding the attribute IsStreamed="false" to an <AudioFileMP3Passthrough> or the attribute IsStreamedOnPC="false" to an <AudioFile>. Since this is not appropriate for music used during a level, you may have to create two <AudioFileMP3Passthrough> entries referencing the same base MP3 file, and two <MP3MusicTrack> entries, if you wish to use a piece of music on both the load screen and the in-game. Also, note that MP3 files used as level load music must be long enough to cover the entire level load in a single playthrough; they will not loop while the level is loading. “Level load music” includes the music referenced by the SaveFileLoadMusic attribute in MiscAudio.xml, the LoadScreenMusic entry in PlayerTemplate.ini, and the LoadScreenMusic attribute in CampaignTemplates.xml.

 

Please note when MODding sound you cannot simply override existing sounds.  They need to be replaced.  In order to accomplish this you will need to create new entries that are referenced instead of the old ones.  For example if you wished to replace all the Predator Tank sounds, you would need to create a completely new Predator Tank referencing the newly created sounds instead of just overriding the existing sound entries.

 

MODding Main Menu Music:

 

In order to MOD the Main Menu music you will need to create a reference to your new music file in this example we will use an mp3 file as a reference.  Then you will need to create a music track entry that references that file.  Finally you will update the MiscAudio block to use your new music reference.  The following is an example showing the file reference and the music track reference:

 

<!—File referenceà

<AudioFileMP3Passthrough id="MODMainScreen" File="AUDIO:TestMusic.mp3" />

<MP3MusicTrack id="ShellLowLODMP3" inheritFrom="MP3MusicTrack:BaseMP3MusicTrack" Volume="60">

<VolumeSliderMultiplier Slider="NONE" Multiplier="1.0" />

<!-- This is a fake to prevent the volume sample from being quieted by the movie playing on the main menu -->

<Filename> MODMainScreen </Filename>                                          

</MP3MusicTrack>

 

The first entry is the file reference, which is used by the MP3MusicTrack type.  The id of the MP3MusicTrack is what we will reference in the updated MiscAudio type.

 

Now locate the MiscAudio.xml file located in the CnC3Xml\Sounds folder.  In there copy the entire MiscAudio block and paste it in the file you are using to MOD the game sound.  In the Sample MOD this is in SoundMOD.xml.  In that block you will need to change the LowLODShellMusc, and the HighLODShellMusic entries to match the new type you’ve created (ShellLowLODMP3):

 

<MiscAudio

                 id="TheMiscAudio"

                 RadarNotifyHarvesterUnderAttackSound=""

                 RadarNotifyStructureUnderAttackSound=""

                 RadarNotifyInfiltrationSound=""       

                 RadarNotifyOnlineSound="RadarOn"             

                 RadarNotifyOfflineSound="RadarOff"            

                 GenericRadarEvent=""

                 BeaconPlacedSound=""

                 BeaconPlacementFailed=""

                 DefectorTimerTickSound=""             

                 DefectorTimerDingSound=""             

                 AllCheerSound=""                      

                 NoCanDoSound=""                       

                 StealthDiscoveredSound=""             

                 StealthNeutralizedSound=""            

                 MoneyDepositSound="CashGaining"                  

                 MoneyWithdrawSound="CashLosing"

                 LowPower="PlayerBasePowerOff"

                 SufficientPower="PlayerBasePowerOn"

                 BuildingDisabled="BuildingGenericPowerOff"                   

                 BuildingReenabled="BuildingGenericPowerOn"                  

                 VehicleDisabled=""                    

                 VehicleReenabled=""                   

                 SplatterVehiclePilotsBrain=""         

                 CrateHeal="CratePickup"

                 CrateShroud="CratePickup"

                 CrateFreeUnit="CratePickup"

                 CrateMoney="CratePickup"

                 UnitPromoted=""                       

                 RepairSparks=""                       

                 EnterCloseCombat=""

                 ExitCloseCombat=""

                 IncomingChatNotification="ChatInGameNotification"

                 PrivateMessageNotification="ChatPrivateMesssageNotification"

                 BuddyMessageNotification=""

                 GameSpyCommunicatorOpen=""           

                 EnabledHotKeyPressed=""

                 DisabledHotKeyPressed=""

                 DisabledButtonClicked=""

                 LowLODShellMusic="ShellLowLODMP3"

                 HighLODShellMusic="ShellLowLODMP3"

                 ScoreScreenMusic="ScoreScreenMusic"

                 ShellMapLoadMusic="Music_BaseBuilding_Unknown"

                 FullScreenSubMenuMusic="Music_BaseBuilding_Unknown"

                 SaveFileLoadMusic="TEMP_RAM_Music360_LoadScreen"

                 CreditsMusic="Music_BaseBuilding_Unknown"

                 VolumeSampleMusic="VolumeSampleMusic"

                 VolumeSampleSoundFX="VolumeSampleSoundFX"

                 VolumeSampleVoice="VolumeSampleVoice"

                 VolumeSampleAmbient="VolumeSampleAmbient"

                 VolumeSampleMovie="VolumeSampleMovie"

                 MissionBriefingCharacterClick="MissionBriefingCharacter"

                 ComboBoxClick=""

                 MPSecondsCountdownBeep="Gui_MPCountdown"

                 RIFThingTemplateReloadedSound=""      

                 RIFObjectsRefreshedSound=""   

                 FastForwardModeOn=""

                 FastForwardModeOff=""

                 RallyPointSet="RallyPointSet"

                 UnableToSetRallyPoint=""

                 PlanningModeOrderGiven="GuiCommandButtonClick"

                 BuildingPlacementSound=""

                 BadBuildingPlacementSound=""

                 WallPlacementSound=""

                 AircraftWheelScreech=""

                 LockonTickSound=""

                 TargetObjectWithSpecialPowerSound=""

                 ObjectiveCompletedSound=""

                 GuiFixedButtonClickedSound="GuiFixedButtonClick"
                 GuiBuildQueueButtonClickedSound="GuiBuildQueueButtonClick" 
                 GuiSelectionRefinementButtonClickedSound="GuiSelectionRefinementButtonClick"

                 GuiFactorySelectionButtonClickedSound="GuiFactorySelectionButtonClick"

                 GuiTogglePowerObjectClickedSound="GuiCommandButtonClick"

                 GuiToggleRepairObjectClickedSound="GuiCommandButtonClick"

                 GuiSellObjectClickedSound="GuiCommandButtonClick"

                 GuiCommandButtonClickedSound="GuiCommandButtonClick"

                 GuiCommandButtonRightClickedSound="GuiCommandButtonRightClick"

                 GuiDisabledCommandButtonClickedSound="GuiDisabledCommandButtonClick"

                 GuiDisabledCommandButtonRightClickedSound="GuiDisabledCommandButtonRightClick"

;                 GuiPlayerPowerButtonClickedSound="GuiPlayerPowerButtonClick"

                 GuiPauseDialogButtonClickedSound="Gui_ShellMapSelect"

                 GuiPauseDialogButtonMouseOverSound="Gui_ShellMapMouseOver"

                 GuiPauseDialogButtonMouseOutSound="Gui_ShellMapMouseOut"

                 GuiYesNoDialogButtonClickedSound="Gui_ShellMapSelect"

                 GuiYesNoDialogButtonMouseOverSound="Gui_ShellMapMouseOver"

                 GuiYesNoDialogButtonMouseOutSound="Gui_ShellMapMouseOut"

/>

 

                        Now when you run the game with your MOD you should hear your new music playing on the main screen.

                        Ambient Sounds: 

There are two ways to add a new ambient sound to a map.  The first is to use the GenericSound type and associate your sound to it.  First you need to create the ambient sound.  Here is an example:

 

<AudioFileMP3Passthrough id="MODAmbientTest" File="AUDIO:MOHAmbientTest.mp3" />

<MP3AmbientStream id="AmbStream_MODAmbientTest"
    inheritFrom="MP3AmbientStream:BaseAmbientStream_MOD"

                    Volume = "45" >

                    <Filename>MODAmbientTest</Filename>

     </MP3AmbientStream>

 

The AudioFileMP3Passthrough points to the file which is then associated with the MP3AmbientStream.  Now to use the GenericSound type you will need to open up World Builder and then your map.  Open the Place Object tool (hotkey for that is P), and then select ByNativeType\Neutral\Audio then pick AGenericSound.  Place this object where you want the ambient sound to play from.  Once you’ve placed the Object select the Select and Move tool (the arrow), and select the newly placed AGenericSound object.  In the Object Properties Window select the Sound Tab.  From there select you’re newly created ambient sound id in the Attached Sound drop down list.

 

The second way to to add an ambient sound is very similar to the first except you also create an object which associates the sound to it.  Then you just place that object in the world and you are done.  Here is an example object:

 

<GameObject

id="AmbStream_MODAmbientTest"

Side="Neutral"

EditorSorting="AUDIO"

KindOf="=$AMBIENTSOUND_KINDOF"

EditorName="AmbStream_MODAmbientTest">

<ArmorSet Armor="NoArmor" />

<Body>

<ImmortalBody

id="ModuleTag_DummyBody"

MaxHealth="1.0" />

</Body>

<AudioArraySound>

<AudioEntry Sound="AmbStream_MODAmbientTest" AudioType="soundAmbient" />

</AudioArraySound>

</GameObject>

 

                           Then when you use the Place Object tool instead of placing AGenericSound you will place the MODAmibentTest object.
